settings.title: INL1Quiz Ciphers
settings.instructions:
Overview

This is the INL1Quiz for the Ciphers lectures. You must get 100% to pass the course. You can retake it. I recommend that you attempt it before the corresponding lecture and then retake it again afterwards.

Grading

If you fail, you will have to go study a bit more and complement your answers. There is a one hour cool-down between attempts. You must have 100% correct answers to pass. Questions will not give partial credit, you get either full score or none.

I suggest that you write down a short motivation for each answer, such that you can review them for the next attempt.

There is no deadline. (Well, the deadline is when you want to get the grade. When all INL1 assignments have a passing grade in Canvas, they'll be automatically transferred to LADOK. This is done once a week, then there might be a few days delay since one of us will have to see the email notification and go certify the results---i.e. click OK---manually in LADOK.)

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Which of the following best describes symmetric encryption?

choices.item_body: Uses the same key for both encryption and decryption.
Uses different keys for encryption and decryption.
Uses a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption.
Utilizes digital certificates for authentication.

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Which algorithms are examples of symmetric encryption?

choices.item_body: RSA
Diffie-Hellman
AES
ElGamal
DES
The One-Time Pad
SHA1
MD5
SHA3

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Which of the following are challenges associated with symmetric encryption in distributed systems?

choices.item_body: Generating keys
Distributing keys
Ensuring high computational speed
Verifying digital signatures

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Which modes of operation are used to prevent pattern leakage in symmetric encryption?

choices.item_body: ECB
CBC
RSA
CTR

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Which property ensures that even if two plaintext blocks are identical, their ciphertext blocks will differ?

choices.item_body: The use of an initialization vector (IV, i.e. a random nonce).
The application of a fixed-key schedule.
The use of public and private keys.
The use of hash functions.

entry.title: Symmetric encrytion
entry.item_body: In symmetric encryption, how does the size of the key influence security?

choices.item_body: Larger keys increase the computational effort required for a brute-force attack.
Larger keys generally reduce security by slowing down encryption.
Key size has little to no effect on security.
The smaller key size of symmetric algorithms (256 bits) compared to assymmetric algorithms (4096 bits), makes symmetric cryptography less secure.

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: What is the significance of using a secure mode of operation in symmetric encryption?

choices.item_body: It ensures that encrypting the same plaintext will always produce the same ciphertext.
It provides both confidentiality and resistance to analysis by introducing randomness.
It eliminates the need for an initialization vector or nonce.
It guarantees that the key can be reused indefinitely without compromise.

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Which attribute is most essential in a secure symmetric encryption algorithm to protect against cryptanalysis?

choices.item_body: Frequent changes to the encryption algorithm.
Strong key randomness and adequate key length.
Automatic use of digital signatures on every encryption.
Integration with asymmetric encryption techniques.

entry.title: Symmetric encryption
entry.item_body: Alice sends a message c = Enc(k_AB, m) to Bob. Bob receives c', computes m' = Dec(k_AB, c'). Enc is an algorithm such as AES. Select all statements that are true.

choices.item_body: The encryption algorithm used is symmetric.
Alice and Bob must have securely shared the key k_AB before Bob can run Dec.
An eavesdropper who intercepts the ciphertext c can easily recover the plaintext m.
Bobâ€™s decryption process correctly inverts the encryption process, yielding m' equal to m under normal conditions.
The confidentiality of message m depends on the secrecy of the key k_AB.
If Enc is a secure scheme, it ensures that the ciphertext c reveals no useful information about the plaintext m to an attacker.
If Enc is a secure scheme, it ensures that when Alice sends her second message c_2 = Enc(k_AB, m_2), the ciphertext c_2 reveals no useful information about the plaintexts m and m_2 to an attacker.
The encryption process automatically guarantees the integrity and authenticity of the message m.
Bob must reject the message if the ciphertext c has been tampered with during transit. But Bob doesn't know if it has been tampered with.
If k_AB is chosen randomly, then no matter how the message m (which fits in one block) is chosen, the ciphertext c will be just as random as k_AB.
